What are the core values of Hinduism?

The #1 core value is rebirth. Without understanding rebirth, it is hard to understand Hinduism or any other Indian religion.

Many religion grapple with the fundamental problem of fairness. How is that life is so unfair to someone and some others so lucky? How do you address the problem that some kid somewhere is suffering for no fault of his?

Hindus answer with the theory of rebirths. You are going to have a lot of rebirths — sometimes lucky, other times not so. You can increase your odds with Karma — the second core value of Hinduism.

Karma is the invisible force that connects all beings with their actions. If you do good actions, you might end up with good deeds either in this or in the next birth. Opposite, if you do bad actions. You don’t have to be dejected that somebody is not punished even when they do wrong. Karma would work this birth or in another. Thus, even if you are in the highest rung of the society and don’t fear for anything in this birth, you don’t want to be doing wrong things.

There is no eternal hell or heaven in Hinduism. Karma can bring you temporary hell or heaven, from which you come back to normal life. Like in the movie Groundhog Day, the cycle keeps repeating and you get tired of it and break it — and attain Moksha. In that case, your soul is merged with God.

The way to reach Moksha, is through the philosophy of Yoga — that has a lot of branches and levels.

Why were temples built?

In modern times, temples are being built anywhere and everywhere:

more for money; less for faith.

In the olden days, the main sanctum was constructed on chosen geographic locations with higher cosmic energy which would be surrounded by the large temples and common to many villages.

The temple structures were huge enough to accommodate hundreds of people inside and they could walk around freely.

There is so much to explain but I shall keep it short with few important information:

1. Temples were built in the precise location to channel that cosmic energy, to all who entered the temple. (This, you can feel in the old temples).

2. Temple tower (gopuram) is pyramid shaped and directly above the sanctum, which is topped by several metals, this is in particular to absorb and harness the energy, from the sun and the cosmos. Now, the sanctum itself wouldn't have any windows or additional doors that might let the energy escape. The only way out is through the pravesha dwara (main door) where the disciples have to gather. This ensures that the positive energy be felt by everyone gathered.

Image source: google

3. These temples have many herbal plants and trees, and it is religiously believed that circling these trees is very beneficial. The real reason for this practice is that just by walking around the trees, breathing fresh air would keep the our immune system strong against many diseases.

4. The god idols are sculpted from specifically selected stones and metals which again contains many traces of minerals which is believed to store the cosmic energy like a battery. These idols are further enriched with many offering such as curd, honey, milk, sugar, rose water, sandalwood and many more items by performing Abhishekam. All these offerings are given to devotees in one or the other form. Sometimes as Prasadam or sometimes are paste which is generally applied on forehead.

The Prasadam helped many poor people in the surrounding villages with nutrition fulfillment who may not even afford all the elements offered.

Image source: google

5. Many old Large Temples served as treasure houses for the kings, and also had underground tunnel system, so in case of danger the King could flee through these secret underground tunnels to a safer place.

6. Many of the offerings like Theertham or Holy water in the temple are generally filled with herbs which protected the devotees with general health.

7. Indians generally walk around their homes barefoot, this is especially emphasized in and around the mandir viz., the temple. This is practiced ideally to keep off the germs and mud carried by the dirty shoes at bay. It is also because the nerve endings at one's foot are massaged and acts as a great acupressure when we walk barefoot.

Image source: google

8. Apart from all these scientific perspective, temples were looked at more as a place where one can let go of his daily ordeals and find peace. The channeled positive energy, reciting of shlokas grounds us down and we will be able to concentrate better.

What is the importance of going to temple?

Dear concerned,

In the distant past, temples were made at the places which were Shakti Sthals/ Power Centres. At these places the energy vibration was much higher. And the sole purpose was that if someone stays there and performs sadhna then he/she could actually channelise the energy present there in order to increase his/her own vibration or in other words doing sadhna there would yield results faster. Also these temples were not limited to Indian culture for example Machu Picchu in Peru, Stonehenge in Britain and many more such places are also the Shakti Sthals/Power Centres of the past.

Dear concerned,

In the distant past, temples were made at the places which were Shakti Sthals/ Power Centres. At these places the energy vibration was much higher. And the sole purpose was that if someone stays there and performs sadhna then he/she could actually channelise the energy present there in order to increase his/her own vibration or in other words doing sadhna there would yield results faster. Also these temples were not limited to Indian culture for example Machu Picchu in Peru, Stonehenge in Britain and many more such places are also the Shakti Sthals/Power Centres of the past.

With time everything changed and so did the temples. New thoughts and philosophies came into being and these ancient places of worship lost their sheen. Worldwide most of the places of worship were constructed by the kings. And they did so to gather like minded people under one roof in order to create a cult. The clergy of the time got a job of maintaining these places of worship and that ensured them an audience. The kings and the clergy have always been dependent upon each other. Both of them used the common men for their specific objectives. Whenever in the history the kings became more powerful, they put a leash on the clergy and whenever the clergy became more powerful, they declared themselves the kings. This power struggle in the name of God has been going on for thousands of years in all the religions across the world. In all the religions of the world, people are encouraged to visit their specific places of worship. In a sense going to a specific place of worship give the common people a sense of belonging, a cult to call their own. At all these places people are told how they are different and better from the rest. Spirituality or the connection of a human being with his/her Creator is a very individual subject. But since the time immemorial the religious leaders needed a like minded herd in order to rule over them. This is how the places of common worship came into being.

In India I am seeing a new rage for constructing temples. We have thousands of cults of different sizes in Hinduism and each one of them is busy in constructing gathering places for their folks calling them temples. I have seen many temples which were constructed in front of my eyes and they all call themselves Prachin Mandir/ Ancient Temple. Here In India temple has become a business model. A certain individual came to me and discussed his plan to construct a temple. He had a blue print of this temple business model which showed that in two year’s time he’ll recover the cost of constructing the temple and then he’ll live off the earnings from that temple for the rest of his life.

At my ancestral place there is a temple which is at least 850 years old. It is primarily a Shiv temple. Some time back an entrepreneurial being became the head of this temple. This temple had a very good vibration and was a secluded one. Now this guy started introducing new Gods to this temple. Now this temple has Ram Parivar, Sai Baba, Shanidev in addition to Radha Krishn and Durga Maa. He did so because he realised that every God has got his/her own customer base. And in order to increase the revenue of the temple, it should have all the possible old and new deities. This once serene and peaceful temple now looks like a shopping mall of Gods. People go there and trade with their choice of God. It has lost its vibration, I no longer go there.

Competition has become fierce among the temples these days and every other temple comes up with a unique marketing idea to increase its footfalls. Many temples in India have named themselves like Manokamna Poorni Mata/ The Goddess who grants wishes temples. The older temples built their empires by declaring that whoever visits these particular temples get their wishes fulfilled. The new ones took a more direct approach and named their temples so. Some temples played on the fear among masses like Shani temples. Sai Baba temples have been the latest rage in Northern India. Like we have a specific discount day every week at most of our departmental stores, these temples also have a specific day in the week attributed to a specific deity to boost their footfalls. The marketing trick is the same.

Earlier there used to be a specific process of constructing a temple. Before placing an idol there used to be Praan Pratishtha / Invoking the element of God in that idol. Now this invocation is a very delicate process. Only a person who is very highly elevated spiritually can perform it. It is extremely rare if not impossible to find a person these days. What priests do in the name of Pran Pratishtha is a big drama nothing else. My senior Guru Ji said that if you don't know who has performed Pran Pratishtha of a particular temple then you should not even bow at that temple.

In case of Shakti Sthals/ Power Centres, you can only feel the higher vibration if your own vibration is a bit higher. Otherwise you’ll simply visit that place and nothing will happen. God is everywhere, She’s not confined to an idol or a temple. You can pray to Her anywhere. Also understand that God is not there to grant your wishes. And God can not be so partial that She only grants wishes if you visit Her temple. Most of my spiritual experiences happened at my place of stay. Instead of going to temples one should make his/her own heart a temple first. Because it is there only you’ll have your glimpse of God.

Do I go to temples? Not really. I do go to some specific temples only because I like the vibration there. Let me tell you about such a temple. In Varanasi there is a small temple at Bengali Tola dedicated to Maa Shamshan Tara. This temple is away from the hustle and bustle of Varanasi temple circuit. Not many people even know about this temple. This place has a wonderful vibration. Whenever I visit this temple, every time I come across a different smell. Sometimes it is a smell of burning human flesh, sometimes that of sandal, sometimes something unique. However there is nothing which can produce a smell like that.

So the point is, don't go to temples thinking that this act of yours will grant your wishes. First upgrade yourself to a certain level so that you can actually feel the vibration that exists there.

Regards

Aghor Bhadra

Is visiting temples mandatory in Hinduism?

No, visiting temples is optional in Hinduism. A Hindu may never visit a temple even once and still be considered a good and devout Hindu. By far the most important are the everyday spiritual practices that Hindus do at home. Most Hindus visit temples only on special occasions, and even then it is optional.

Is Shanti Parva important for Hinduism?

Yes, the Shanti Parva (“Book of Peace”), the longest of the books of the Mahabharata, is indeed important for Hinduism. As a Hindu, in high school I had to listen to my teacher read long passages from Shanti Parva while my fellow students and I wrote it down verbatim in our notebooks, and then we held discussions on it, mainly focusing on Bhishma’s teachings on Dharma and justice.

Shanti Parva’s discussion of Varna is also highly important for Hinduism. In it, Rishi Bharadwaja proclaims that there is no basis for caste discrimination when all groups of people experience the same desire, the sam

Yes, the Shanti Parva (“Book of Peace”), the longest of the books of the Mahabharata, is indeed important for Hinduism. As a Hindu, in high school I had to listen to my teacher read long passages from Shanti Parva while my fellow students and I wrote it down verbatim in our notebooks, and then we held discussions on it, mainly focusing on Bhishma’s teachings on Dharma and justice.

Shanti Parva’s discussion of Varna is also highly important for Hinduism. In it, Rishi Bharadwaja proclaims that there is no basis for caste discrimination when all groups of people experience the same desire, the same anger, the same fear, the same grief, the same fatigue, the same hunger, the same love, and other essential emotional nature; everyone is born the same way, carries the same blood and bile in their body, and they die the same way. Maharishi Bhrigu agrees and proclaims that the difference between Varnas is only for differentiation of work; that all Sanskara rites of passage should be open to people of all Varnas. Shanti Parva clearly teaches that birth and caste initiation do not determine a person’s merit; only their actual conduct and virtues. Thus there are no superior or inferior Varnas. These teachings are very important for Hinduism.

Shanti Parva also contains teachings on proper political governance that are still fully relevant today. It teaches that a prosperous nation must be guided by truth, justice, and compassion, and that the duty of a ruler and the cabinet is to enable people to be happy, pursue truth, and act sincerely. It has guidance on just and progressive taxation, proportionate and humane criminal sentencing, avoiding harsh and capital punishments, etc. It teaches that the proper function of a ruler or politician is to rule according to Dharma while leading a simple life, not using their power to enjoy luxuries, and that the Dharma of a ruler is to work toward the upliftment of all living beings, including animals such as wild forest birds. It also teaches that a ruler should develop a strong bond with the people of the nation. It gives guidance that the best law is one that enhances the welfare of all living beings, without injuring any specific group. It also recommends that a nation should welcome and protect refugees. I think many a modern politician (Hindu or otherwise) could benefit profoundly from following the Shanti Parva’s guidance.

Shanti Parva also gives a scathing discussion of war as deeply rooted in hatred, and that the most important results of war are not victory or defeat but rather the great destruction and death caused to living beings. It also discusses the distinction between legitimate political power and tyranny, and that people have a moral duty to revolt against tyranny.

Why is meditation so important in Hinduism?

“Meditation” is a 4 fold process in Hindu spiritual practice. It consists of pratyahāra (withdrawl of the attention from the external world), dhāraṇa (concentration on a deity or mantra or breath.) dhyāna (immersion) in which the attention becomes totally immersed in the object of meditation and then samādhi (absorption) and transcendental state which arises from the afore mentioned process.

The purpose of meditation is to transform oneself i.e. to rid oneself of all the afflictive emotions; selfishness, anger, delusion, hubris, greed and malicious envy and to obtain a greater insight into one’s essential nature (ātma-bodha).

As Aaron has said - it has hardly taught or practiced nowadays even though it is mentioned and emphasized in all the sacred texts and by all the great achāryas, especially the Tantras where detailed instructions are given.

The emphasis nowadays is on external acts of piety rather than on personal transformation through introspection and insight.

Hinduism: What is the importance of Ekadashi?

Since time immemorial in Vedic Culture, Yogis and sages had been giving the importance for diverting sense actions from materialism to divinity. Ekadashi fasting is one of that spiritual practice.

As per hindu scripture, there are two words in Ekadashi Eka (1) and Dasha (10). Ten actions of ten senses and mind from worldly objects to God is the true Ekadashi.

It is said that the Importance of Ekadashi was narrated by Lord Krishna to Yudhisthira, the eldest of Pandava brothers. Devotees observe the fast to seek prosperity, and attain mokshalater in life.

In the Brahma-vaivarta Purana it is said that one who observes fasting on Ekadasi day is freed from all kinds of reactions to sinful activities and advances in pious life.

Different Ekadashi has different story behind it.

Lord Krishna to Arjuna in Bhagvad Gita, chapter 1

“If a person fasts on ekadasi, I will burn up all his sins and bestow upon him My transcendental abode…..Indeed, ekadasi is the most meritorious day for destroying all kinds of sins, and it has appeared in order to benefit everyone.”

According to Hindu scriptures, Ekadasi and movement of the moon has a direct correlation with the human mind. It is believed that during Ekadasi, our mind attains maximum efficiency giving the brain a better capacity to concentrate.

spiritual seekers are said to devote the two monthly days of Ekadasi in extreme worship and meditation owing to its favourable influence on the mind.

Devotees fast on this day, observe vigil the whole night by doing Pooja and meditation. Some do not take even a drop of water. Those who are unable to fast completely can take some light fruit and milk. By fasting we will become alert and attentive and devotion towards God develops and become intense. It also checks the emotions and senses.

The story of Ekadashi

In Satyuga, there lived a demon called Murdanav. He terrorized all good people and devotees on the earth as well as he scared all the Devaas also. So Devaas left heaven and took refuge to Lord Vishnu. They prayed lord Vishnu to protect them. God’s mercy towards his devotees is limitless. So he took off immediately on His fastest vehicle “Garuda”. He fought continuously for 1000 years with Murdanav of unbelievable strength and still he was fighting with full energy and power. So Lord Vishnu decided to change his strategy.

lord, Vishnu acted as if He was exhausted by the battle and hid in a cave in Himalayas. He decided to take a nap in this huge cave. Lord Vishnu along with all his ten senses and the mind inside, was taking a rest.

Murdanav reached to the cave by chasing lord Vishnu. He saw him sleeping inside the cave and followed Him. He took his sword to kill lord Vishnu. As he was about to swing the sword, suddenly an extremely beautiful & luminous lady playing with a sword emerged from lord Vishnu’s body.

Murdanav lured to her beauty & asked her to marry him. She said, “I would marry who can defeat me in battle” Murdanav agreed to her proposal. He started fighting with that divine lady. Eventually during the fight that divine lady defeated & slayed Murdanav.

Hearing the noise of fight, lord Vishnu woke up and saw that lady who killed Murdanav. Lord Vishnu called that lady, who emerged from Himself, by the name Ekadashi. That was the eleventh day of the waxing moon. Lord Vishnu pleased by her deed & said to ask a boon. The Ekadashi asked to Lord Vishnu that ‘as I evolved from your Ekadash Indriyas (eleven senses of the body) I shall be known as Ekadashi. I am filled with penance so I desire that people should observe Ekadashi Vrat and control their Ekadash Indriyas (Senses) on this day. On the day of my Vrat, no one should consume grains such as rice, wheat, beans etc.

Lord Vishnu agreed and ever since all Hindus perform Ekadashi Vrat by fasting or eating Falahari foods on the 11th day of bright half of the moon & dark half of the moon. Also Lord Vishnu said that devotees who observe the Ekadashi day with fasting and prayers would have his choicest blessings! This story is based on Padama Puranam, a Hindu Scripture.

According to the Vishnu Purana. Vaikuntha is located 26,200,000 yojanas (209,600,000 miles) above Satyaloka (also known as Brahmaloka since it is the celestial abode of Lord Brahma).

The location of Vaikuntha coincides with the Makara Rashi i.e. the Capricorn constellation.

Vaikunta Dwaram’ or ‘the gate to the Lord's Inner Sanctum’ is opened on this day. The Margashirsha Shukla Paksha Ekadashi in the Lunar calendar is known as a 'Mokshada Ekadashi.' Special prayers, yagnas, discourses and speeches are arranged at Vishnu temples across the world on this auspicious day.

One version of the cosmology states that Vishnu's eye is at the South Celestial from where he watches the cosmos.

The Rigveda states: tad viṣṇoḥ paramaṁ padaṁ sadā paśyanti sūrayaḥ

(The gods are always looking to that supreme abode of Lord Vishnu), referring to Vaikuntha.

Ekadashi is also correlated with Planet Vaikuntha.

  • Ekadashi fasting (Upavas) is Agna (command) of God, so it is best option for Devotee.
  • Ekadashi fasting is considered equal to bath done crores of time in holy river Ganga.
  • Ekadashi fasting is considered equal to cows donation done crores of time. Because purpose of cow donations and Ganga Snan (bath) is controlling senses and pleasing of God, that both happens herein Ekadashi fasting.
  • Ekadashi is considered as a Maha-vrat (greatest of all). As per Vedic calendar, every vrat (fasting and rituals) has specific deities; The head of Ekadashi Vrat is Bhagavan Narayan Himself.
  • Ekadasi fasting is greater in merit than staying and visiting places of pilgrimage, performing fire sacrifices or even aswamedha sacrifice.
  • Single ekadasi fast earns the same merit as the one who feeds 1000 mendicants every day for 60,000 years.
  • It prevents and cures illnesses and diseases as it helps in the detoxification of the body and cleansing of bowel system.
  • It gives 10 times merit in comparison to a person giving away in charity 1000 cows to a learned brahmana.
  • According to Brahma- Vaivarta Purana, it is believed that Lord Vishnu removes the sins of those who observe this fast. The obstacles to spiritual progress are removed and perfection in life is achieved.
  • Sage Vasista in Narada Purana says, “Neither Ganga, Kasi, Kurukshetra, Yamuna, Reva, Vedika, Gaya, Pushkara and Chandrabhaga, none of them are equal to the day of Lord Hari, Ekadasi. Even if one fasts on ekadasi unknown to others, all his sins are burnt at once and he attains the spiritual world.”
  • Ekadasi fasting is believed to liberate one from the cycle of births and deaths.

New findings in modern age benefits of Ekadashi Fasting:-

  • It purifies one’s mind, body and soul.
  • Fasting will clean the toxins out of the body especially in the digestive system.
  • It destroys the 90% possibility of any kind of cancer.
  • The body will feel light and energetic after fasting.

According to research of above scientists if anyone would fast for 20 days in the whole year at least for 10 hours in a day that person would not get cancer or the ratio & chances of not getting cancer would be 90%.

This research of scientist in the field of medical got Nobel Prize in year 2018.

It is also mentioned in all the Puranas that Ekadashi is the best of all fasts.

Why is water important to Hinduism?

Water is important in ALL the worlds religions since the beginning of time. In all religions creation occurs through and from water. Life is impossible without water.

In the Bible book of Genesis first chapter we have the Spirit of Yahweh hovering over the waters which he then divides, separating the waters above i.e. heaven from the waters below i.e. sea and thus creating the world - this is based on an earlier Mesopotamian myth of Marduk doing exactly the same. (Most of the myths of the Bible are borrowed from Mesopotamia).

In the Quran it is also mentioned that Allah’s throne is over the wate

Water is important in ALL the worlds religions since the beginning of time. In all religions creation occurs through and from water. Life is impossible without water.

In the Bible book of Genesis first chapter we have the Spirit of Yahweh hovering over the waters which he then divides, separating the waters above i.e. heaven from the waters below i.e. sea and thus creating the world - this is based on an earlier Mesopotamian myth of Marduk doing exactly the same. (Most of the myths of the Bible are borrowed from Mesopotamia).

In the Quran it is also mentioned that Allah’s throne is over the waters (11:7) and that he created every animal from water (24:45) and also man from water. (25:54)

In Hinduism too water is associated with creation - Vishnu lies upon the waters. Water is the embodiment of Vishnu as preserver. Water is the means of purification, and the abode of divine powers. The Waters are goddesses. At every ceremony jars of water are decorated and worshiped. Rivers are the arteries of the earth and the givers of life hence they are regarded as sacred. Pools of water are the doorways to the spiritual (nishkala) realm hence they are called tīrtha or fords.

What is Janeu's importance in Hinduism?

“Janeu”, also called “yajnopavItam” in Sanskrit is the sacred thread worn by traditional Brahmins, Kshatriyas and Vaishyas.

Thousands of years ago, it signified that a person has studied Veda and is trained in performance of yajnas. Then later, by association, it came to mean purity of thought, word and deed.

However, in the present day, I don’t see even Brahmins studying Veda or following shAstra. So in present times, wearing a sacred thread has lost all meaning. It has become just a meaningless ritual.

I know traditionalists and ritualists will object to what I have said. But it is the truth.

Wearing a sacred thread without having studied Veda is like a beggar who finds a nice suit in the garbage and wears it, thinking he is a rich man.

Now, I’m not saying that Brahmins should cut up their sacred threads. I’m saying, if they still wear sacred thread, let them make an effort to lead a true Brahmin life as prescribed in scriptures. At least, let them study Veda for a few years and earn the qualification to wear the sacred thread.

A Scientific Possibility:-

  1. If air is trapped within a shell of silica it would look a stone but would actually be very light and would thus float.
  2. Another example is Ice. When it put into glass having liquid, ice floats on liquid a& after some time it sinks.
  3. Another prime example is "Pumice" stone.
  4. Pumice is one such stone floats on water.
  5. Pumice is the name given to the hardened foam of lava when it comes out of a volcano.
  6. The inside of a volcano has very high pressure, and can be as hot as 1600° C.
  7. When the lava comes out of the volcano, it meets the cool air (and some times sea water), which is arround 25° C.
  8. Air and water were mixed in the lava bubble out, as pressure falls.
  9. The huge difference in temperature gives the lava cold shock, so it freeze almost immediately.
  10. So the bubble get trapped in the freezing stone, giving it a very spongy appearance.
  11. In some case of pumice, the bubbles can make upto 90% of the volume.

(2). Hinduism is Historical

  1. Rig Vedic River Saraswati was dried up in BCE 1950.

The dehydration of this river is caused by detention of the tributaries by the Yamuna River and Indus River System . Also the cutting down of trees: Deforestation and overgrazing are the other reasons of the dehydration of the river later and the desiccation in most of its drainage basin. Though originally all these events took place much before than 1900 BCE, it is believed by some historians, researchers and environmentalists that all this might have taken place in the 1900 BCE itself.

The images show that it was 8 km wide in places and that it dried up 4,000 years ago.

9. World’s oldest language:- Sanskrit

Origin (according to first appearance as script) - 2000 BCE

Considered to be the 'language of the Gods', Sanskrit is the ancient language of India. The earliest example of this language can be found in the second millennium BC. The language is still spoken by small group of people. The influence of Sanskrit on several western languages is known to all. The basic language of computers were also constructed along the principles of Sanskrit

(1). Rig Veda(BCE 2000-BCE 1900):- The text is a collection of 1,028 hymns and 10,600 verses, organized into ten books (Mandalas). The exact century of the Rigveda’s composition is unknown, and estimated by scholars to be around 2000 to 1900 BCE.

(2). Yajur Veda(BCE 1900-BCE 1800):- The exact century of Yajurveda's composition is unknown, and estimated by scholars to be around 1900 to 1800 BCE.

(3). Atharva Veda(BCE 1800-BCE 1700):- The Atharvaveda is composed in Vedic Sanskrit, and it is a collection of 730 hymns with about 6,000 mantras, divided into 20 books. The exact century of Atharvaveda's composition is unknown, and estimated by scholars to be around 1800 to 1700 BCE.

(4). Sam Veda(BCE 1700-BCE 1600):- One of the four Vedas, it is a liturgical text whose 1,875 verses are primary derived from the Rigveda after 300 years of compositin of Rig Veda. The exact century of Samveda's composition is unknown, and estimated by scholars to be around 1700 to 1600 BCE.

What are the benefits of temples in Hinduism?
Originally Answered: What are the benefits of temples in Hindu?

Sanatana Dharma (the native name for Hinduism) has been developed with a objective of creating a positive world where every single being on earth can be positive, happy and peacefully coexist with other beings.

Our ancient Rishis, who were scientists, researchers, scholars and innovators, discovered scientifically how to create positive energy and Positivity.

When we visit places of worship and are positive, at an individual level, it helps us stay healthy - Physically, mentally, emotionally and intellectually. It can make us a better version of ourselves. This positivity also radiates to people around us, distributing the same individual benefits to them as well. But, it won't happen instantly. It happens gradually, over time.

Traditionally, places of workship have been centres of positivity, of positive energy. Irrespective of the religion.

Source: Facebook

This is not due to the "God" that resides there but due to the worshippers' and priests' positive prayers over several years and decades. The cumulative power of human thoughts is just too powerful to be ignored. The Positivity of the place is also due to fact that the place is typically kept clean to maintain 'purity' and sanctity. Generally, natural elements are extensively used there, like water, milk, fruits, flowers, bunch of feathers, raw wood, etc.

That is also why older places of worship are considered more energetic and powerful, not because they are big or because they are part of history and have been constructed by Kings.

Source: ‘School of Vedic Science’ Facebook Page.

Hinduism made it more scientific. It brought in a system where verses were chanted from a scientifically developed, positive language like Sanskrit. (Speaking Sanskrit creates positive vibrations inside us) Every element used in a temple, be it the metals, the stone the statues were made of, elements used during the ritual, etc were designed to retain, store, enhance positive energy, if not amplify them further and pass it on to worshippers. The 'Mantras' and rituals performed in front of the gods were so designed that each one had a different positive effect. Hence, we attribute those effects to the respective gods. Be it

* courage and bravery with Lord Hanuman or
* learning and knowledge with Goddess Saraswathi or
* wealth and prosperity with Goddess Lakshmi.

Temples were constructed to house multiple gods so that worshippers received a mix of all positive effects or traits for all round development and well-being.

Source: Pinterest

How does this help in creating a positive place, you ask?

Traditionally, people preferably staying in and around these places of worship or rather, places of Positivity. Residences were built around these places of worship. This is so that the positive energy from the place of worship emanates all around it. Also, when people were in distress, they could just reach out, worship, get positive and look forward to well being. This still holds true for places having ancient temples like Kashi, Srirangam, Rameswaram, Tirupati, Udupi, Guruvayoor, Puri, etc.

Place : Srirangam with the temple at the centre and town built around it.

Source: Saffron Flag Facebook Page

The other practice followed more in ancient times and followed even today in some mosques is - places of worship give shelter, food and water to the needy, homeless and to travelers completely for free. This energises their weak self and puts them on track for further growth thanks to the positive energy in that place. People could sleep in a temple, bathe in temple ponds, eat ‘Prasadam’ which is the positive food provided by temples 2 - 3 times a day. Unlike the present, in old times, Prasadams used to be uncooked, Satvic diet like fruits that were used during god's worship. If people are idle, they can also engage in community service or seva in the temple premises. Even today, elderly people, after retirement, practice community service at temples. This gives them positive strength when age renders them weak and negative.

What is the difference between a temple and a matha in Hinduism?

In Hinduism, a temple is intended primarily for the worship of Murtis (holy icons) of deities.

A matha is a monastery. Its primary purpose is to be a residence for sanyasis (Hindu monks), and to meet all of their needs. Often spiritual classes are also taught at mathas, far more often than at temples.

Put simply: a temple is a Gods’ house. A matha is a monks’ house.

Often they are immediately adjoining each other, like here (temple on left, matha on right):

It is a small platform to keep the offerings. Bhakti is of three types.

They break the coconut which symbolises the Individuality; The external hard shell which symbolises the Desire, Anger, Hate, pride etc. then one reaches the white pulp is Sattvic nature, and enjoys the pure sweet water blissfully.

Sattvik Bhakti; They break the coconut with the above intent.

Rajasik Bhakta ; Counts the number of coconut with business mentality.

Tamasik Bhata; Offers animal sacrifices to get rid of Animality with in himself, It could a Animal made of Gold or Silver or some metal.

How important is authenticity in Hinduism?

authenticity

ô″thĕn-tĭs′ĭ-tē

noun

  1. The quality or condition of being authentic, trustworthy, or genuine.
  2. The quality of being authentic, or entitled to acceptance as authoritative, genuine, true, or correct: as, the authenticity of the Scriptures or of a document; the authenticity of a portrait; the authenticity of a statement.
  3. The quality of being authentic or of established authority for truth and correctness.

Is authenticity important only to Hindus or to everyone regardless of religious persuasion?

What is the importance of temples in India?

The philosophical construct termed the “ultimate truth” is an abstraction that is beyond human comprehension. So Hindu philosophy improvises to give you a feel for the “ultimate truth”, a path or focal point for your “bhakti”, by using natural phenomena as constant reminders of the abstract.

Over thousands of years, these became personalized so that people find it easier to relate to them. This is the colorful stories in our smriti, which attempts to explain the abstract philosophical constructs of the Veda in a simple, easy to remember format, and usually combines this with some phenomena or e

The philosophical construct termed the “ultimate truth” is an abstraction that is beyond human comprehension. So Hindu philosophy improvises to give you a feel for the “ultimate truth”, a path or focal point for your “bhakti”, by using natural phenomena as constant reminders of the abstract.

Over thousands of years, these became personalized so that people find it easier to relate to them. This is the colorful stories in our smriti, which attempts to explain the abstract philosophical constructs of the Veda in a simple, easy to remember format, and usually combines this with some phenomena or event that would also indicate the date or period in which this was written, so that as knowledge grows, these stories can also be updated periodically (this isn’t happening).

Once you give this deity a persona, it becomes easy for people to relate to it as an entity with an abode, the temple. What must be remembered is that temples have thousands of designs based on a science, each with its specific purpose.

To the Hindu, the temple is not a structure, it is an abode of the “living deity”, a personification of the ultimate truth about our own true nature, and that of the world around us. It is a outward representation of an inward view, the union, a representation of a darshan of the highest reality. The environment in temples is designed in a manner that, for those who follow the practice of “bhaktiyog”, opens the portals of higher spiritual dimensions in time.

Temple designs are also an aspect of the diversity of Hindu philosophical practices. Some temple practices, like Sabarimala for instance, is laid out in the form of a syllabus for the apprentice seeker of the brahmavidya.

Why is Ahimsa important to Hinduism?

As a broad governing principle, it is perfectly in harmony with human nature.

But it doesn’t imply absolute “non-violence”! It’s real import is the “prevention of greater harm”, and as such it calls for proactive monitoring and early action so as to nip problems in the bud before they take on a life of its own. This proactive monitoring is of course not par for the course, as it includes summary death penalty. It is therefore executed only by those who are specialized in the tradition, understand the norms of behaviour, the tolerances or limits of what can be considered as acceptable behaviour, and also someone very conversant with the prevailing laws of the land.

Where is the largest Hindu temple, and in which state or country?

The largest Hindu temple is Angkor Wat at Angkor, Cambodia. It is not only the largest Hindu temple but the largest monument of any religion in the world, covering 402 acres. However it is no longer an ‘active’ Hindu temple with priests performing the rituals there, but mostly a ruin in the jungles.

The largest active, functioning Hindu temple is the Sri Ranganathasvamy Temple in Tiruchirapalli, Tamil Nadu, India.

In terms of largest number of pilgrims, donations, etc. (rather than physical size), the largest Hindu temple is the Venkateswara Temple at Tirumala, Tirupati, Andhra Pradesh, India. It is the most-visited holy place in the world, of any religion.
